dc:description:
NEXN was originally evaluated for DCM by the ClinGen DCM GCEP on February 14 2020. Evidence of the association of this gene with DCM was re-evaluated using SOP v10 on November 15 2024. As a result, the classification changed. A summary of the information contributing to the classification of this gene at the time of re-evaluation is summarized herein:

NEXN was evaluated for autosomal dominant dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM). NEXN encodes a filamentous actin (F-actin)-binding protein that also binds to RyR2 and Jph2, is a pivotal component of the junctional membrane complex, is required for initiation and formation of T-tubules and is important Ca2+ homeostasis in the heart (Liu et al 2019, PMID: 30982350; Spinozzi et al 2020, PMID: 32635769). Human genetic evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and case-control data. At least 30 heterozygous rare variants (both truncating and non-truncating) have been described in patients with DCM. Rare NEXN variants (truncating and non-truncating jointly) are significantly enriched in DCM compared to controls (Mazzarotto et al, 2020, PMID: 31983221). The heterozygous variant NM_144573.3(NEXN): c.1949_1951del p.(Gly650del) was found in 6/1000 DCM patients analyzed in Germany. All 6 shared an identical haplotype over a large genomic region surrounding the NEXN gene suggesting a founder effect. The variant occurred in 155/1461510 gnomAD (v4.1) alleles, and overexpression of the variant in zebrafish and mouse models results in DCM (Hassel et al 2009, PMID: 19881492; Liu et al 2020, PMID: 32814711). 
This gene-disease relationship is supported by experimental evidence. NEXN RNA and protein are highly expressed in the myocardium (Zhao et al, 2001, PMID: 12053183, Hassel et al, 2009, PMID: 19881492). Nexn knock-out (KO) zebrafish (using morpholino-modified antisense oligonucleotides) and mouse models (using cre-loxP) show severe, progressive DCM (Hassel et al, 2009, PMID: 19881492; Aherrahrou et al, 2016, PMID: 26659360; Liu et al, 2019, PMID: 30982350). A in vivo mouse rescue model has also demonstrated restoration of cardiomyocyte function in Nexn KO and G645del (equivalent to human G650del) mice following AAV-mediated Nexn gene replacement (Shao et al 2024, PMID: 38783323). Western blot analyses and pull-down results showed that NEXN was coimmunoprecipitated with both Jph2 and RyR2 (proteins from the T tubule) (Liu et al, 2019, PMID: 30982350). Confocal analysis of postnatal control and Nexn KO cardiomyocytes showed that organized T-tubules were completely absent in KO cells (Liu et al, 2019, PMID: 30982350). 

In summary, there is strong evidence to support this gene-disease relationship Three years must elapse from the first proposal of the relationship definitively, with no convincing contradictory evidence emerging. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Dilated Cardiomyopathy Working Group on November 15 2024

evidence.dc:description: Default score of 0.5 was already given for expression in heart in PMID: 12053183

Immunohistology of zebrafish hearts revealed restriction of nexilin expression to the myocardium, whereas endocardium and pericardium were devoid of nexilin. Nexilin is localized in distinct thin stripes that alternated with staining for thick filaments. In rat heart sections, nexilin staining was also flanked by thick filaments and colocalized with the known Z-disk protein calsarcin (Fig. 1h,i). These findings establish nexilin as a Z-disk protein of heart and skeletal muscle. In PMID: 30982350, the authors showed that (1) NEXN is a pivotal component of the junctional membrane complex (JMC) and is required for initiation and formation of T-tubules, (2) is important for Ca2+ homeostasis in the heart and (3) is not located in the Z-disk but is instead localized to the JMC.
evidence.rdfs:label: Hassel_Expression in myocardium and Z-disk region

evidence.dc:description: not known
evidence.rdfs:label: Zhao_expression in fetal and adult heart

evidence.dc:description: Alteration in Ca2+ handling is seen in DCM. Variants in RYR2 can result in CPVT and variants JPH2 can result in ARVD.
evidence.rdfs:label: Liu_Expression and pull-down experiments

evidence.dc:description: Disrupted T-tubule organization and calcium regulation leads to impaired contractility, ventricular thinning, and heart failure seen in dilated cardiomyopathy.
evidence.rdfs:label: Spinozzi_calcium + imaging experiments

evidence.dc:description: In hearts from individuals carrying either the NEXN G650del (H-1824) or the NEXN Y652C (H-1165) mutations, we found disruption of sarcomeric units and detached and blurry Z-disks
evidence.rdfs:label: Hassel_Ultrastructural analysis of myocardial biopsy

evidence.dc:description: developed dilated ventricles with systolic dysfunction and wall thinning => DCM
evidence.rdfs:label: Aherrahrou_mouse KO using cre-loxP and Gt(ROSA)26Sortm

evidence.dc:description:
Homozygous c and gKO (all three) mice showed increased left ventricular diameter and reduced systolic cardiac function and all died before day 12. 
DCM was severe and progressive, with cardiac dysfunction first evident at P1, severe left ventricular dilation starting from P5, collagen-positive mural masses evident by P7, and thinning of the cardiac walls clearly visible at P10.  Absence of elastic fibers and presence of fibrin suggested collagen-positive masses were thrombi rather than endocardial fibroelastosis.
 At P1 SR stress is observed as the expression (RNA and protein) of Ca2+ handling proteins were altered.
evidence.rdfs:label: Liu_mouse KO using Sox2-cre-loxP gKO

evidence.dc:description: 87% (103/194) of injected embryo’s develop heart failure due to dilated atria and ventricles with severely reduced systolic function.
evidence.rdfs:label: Hassel_NEXN KO in Zebrafish

evidence.dc:description:
Control: AAV-cTnt-EGFP injected into NEXN gKO mice. These mice lost weight, developed DCM, died at P10.

AAV-cTnT-mNexn) was injected into NEXN gKO mice, Injected mice gained weight, survived for 1-month (time of assessment) with normal cardiac morphology and parameters, including normal fractional shortening. 

Function also restored to homozygous G645del mice (corresponding to G650del in humans) using AAV-cTnt-mNEXN or hNEXN. Expression levels ~30% of wildtype,
evidence.rdfs:label: Shao_Liu gKO mouse rescue

evidence.dc:description: Scored with gKO model (Liu_mouse KO using Sox2-cre-loxP gKO)

Homozygous c and gKO (all three) mice showed increased left ventricular diameter and reduced systolic cardiac function and all died before day 12. 
DCM was severe and progressive, with cardiac dysfunction first evident at P1, severe left ventricular dilation starting from P5, collagen-positive mural masses evident by P7, and thinning of the cardiac walls clearly visible at P10.  Absence of elastic fibers and presence of fibrin suggested collagen-positive masses were thrombi rather than endocardial fibroelastosis.
 At P1 SR stress is observed as the expression (RNA and protein) of Ca2+ handling proteins were altered.
evidence.rdfs:label: Liu_mouse KO using XMLC2-cre or Tnnt2-cre (cardiac)

evidence.dc:description: Zebrafish phenotype does not recapitulate DCM: nexn−/− embryos showed reduced cardiac contractility without an enlarged and dilated ventricle in under physiological conditions.
Zebrafish phenotype does not recapitulate DCM.
evidence.rdfs:label: Hofeichner_CRISPR.Cas-9 KO zebrafish model

evidence.dc:description: After injection of 250 pg of NEXNG650del mRNA, 101 of 274 (~37%) of the injected embryos developed a DCM indistinguishable from MO-nexn–injected embryos (hearts of NEXN-G650del–expressing embryos were severely dilated, with markedly reduced systolic function and Z-disk disruption. Similar results by ectopic expression of Y652C or P611T mutated nexilin
evidence.rdfs:label: Hassel_NEXN variants tested in Zebrafish

evidence.dc:description: Homozygous G645del mice express about 30% of the Nexn expressed by WT controls and exhibited a progressive DCM characterized by reduced T-tubule formation, with disorganization of the transverse-axial tubular system.
evidence.rdfs:label: Liu_G645del mouse (human G650del model)

Not scored for dominant disease. Unlike other reports, this patient is homozygous, with severe DCM, died at 2 weeks. Heterozygous parents were unaffected, as was carrier paternal grandfather.

6 probands with variant in 1000 DCM probands (29x in 279530 gnomAD alleles). 3 informative meioses
across 3 families. Because of shared haplotype of 6 probands and control with p.Gly650del and shared haplotype developing DCM 10 years later, score 1 for all 6 cases.

NEXN (rare LoF+missense) variants significantly enriched in DCM (1498 patients from  secondary diagnostic referral cohort) compared to controls (60706 controls from EXAC) (NEXN 2.9% vs 0.7%, P=1.6×10–2)

caseCohort.detectionMethod: Primary cases and controls underwent identical sequencing and bioinformatics data processing on the TruSight Cardio panel (see also Pua CJ et al., J Cardiovasc Transl Res. 2016 9 3–11_PMID 26888179)
